Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(2) Summary

Microservices come with the promise of decreasing the dependencies between teams and thereby increasing the velocity of developing and evolving digital capabilities. While Microservices can help with that, it is important to understand that they are just an architecture pattern, and that other aspects are equally important for realizing the promise of Microservices. One of these aspects is DevOps which means that teams have more autonomy and responsibility regarding the operational aspects of the services that they own. In this presentation we look at how Microservices and DevOps relate, and which other aspects are equally important when it comes to increasing the velocity of your organization.

Microservices as a Pattern

Outline (Microservices as a Pattern)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Microservices as a Pattern [9]

  4. DevOps [5]
  5. Conclusions [2]
Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(7) Bottom-Up Motivation: Service Scalability

  • Build modularized components that can be scaled individually
    • Monitoring allows insights into system status and load
    • Rapid Provisioning allows to react quickly when new capacity is required
    • Rapid Deployment means simple ways to develop/test/start/scale services
  • Microservice implementations are more flexible than integrated approaches
    • Scaling can be done per service instead of scaling bigger deployment units
    • Code can be retired more easily by removing services from deployment
    • Fewer unintended side-effects since all interactions are through APIs


Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(8) Top-Down Motivation: Digital Transformation

  • IT capabilities and management often are not aligned
    • Capabilities are growing and business demands are growing as well
    • Management becomes complex and impacts execution speed
  • There is a difference in separating interfaces and implementations
    • Interfaces are useful for accessing capabilities
    • Implementations must support easy modifications and additions
  • The first wave of API focus (SOA) focused on interfaces only
    • Focusing on APIs as business-aligned capabilities is a necessary first step
    • Agility suffers when implementations are not business-aligned
    • Conway's Law [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_law] means that changing implementation structure can be hard


Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(9) Conway's Law

Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure. [http://www.melconway.com/Home/Conways_Law.html] (Mel Conway [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melvin_Conway])


Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(10) The SOA Crisis

  • SOAP-style SOA are traditional IT monoliths exposing some capabilities
  • MSA #1 goal is to create a loosely coupled service landscape
    • Shared data storage creates coupling
    • Shared infrastructure creates coupling
    • Shared libraries create coupling
    • Loose coupling allows to pick the right tool for the job
    • Loose coupling allows to refactor/retire as required
    • Loose coupling blurs the public/partner/private lines
  • Using APIs is one of the few overlaps between SOAP-style SOA and MSA


Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(11) Microservices are SOA!



Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(12) Microservices are SOA done Right!

  • Decouple implementations and not just interfaces
  • Velocity is determined by how hard it is to make changes
  • The biggest problem is not access to capabilities but capability agility
    • Providing access to capabilities is better than doing nothing
    • Agile management of the capability landscape goes further than that
  • Microservices apply Web architecture to Enterprise IT
    • Implementation details are completely invisible to service users
    • Service consumption only uses well-defined and uniform interfaces


Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

Microservices as a Pattern Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

Microservices and APIs

Outline (Microservices and APIs)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Microservices as a Pattern [9]
  3. Microservices and APIs [3]
  4. DevOps [5]
  5. Conclusions [2]
Microservices and APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(17) There is no Microservices API

  • Microservices are all about how to implement services
  • APIs are all about how to interact with services
  • Microservices are an implementation detail from the API perspective
  • Microservice-implemented APIs might exhibit certain properties
    • Changing more often because of faster implementation cycles
    • More diverse API landscapes because of more autonomy
    • Smaller scope because of solutions targeted at specific problems


Microservices and APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(18) Designing Microservice APIs

  • API consumers just use an API and not a Microservice API
    • Microservice API design is no different from API design in general
    • Tighter coupling may be acceptable for specific scenarios (BFF pattern [http://samnewman.io/patterns/architectural/bff/])
  • Balancing autonomy/diversity and coherence/usability is necessary
    • Microservices should have freedom to design their APIs
    • API design should be driven by design culture and patterns


Microservices and APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(19) Focus Areas for Microservice APIs

  • Be explicit about openness and extensibility
  • Provide glue that makes combining services easy
    • At the minimal level, always use global, unique, and persistent identifiers
    • Consider using hypermedia as a way to support service orchestration
  • Be explicit about how services signal end-of-life


DevOps

Outline (DevOps)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Microservices as a Pattern [9]
  3. Microservices and APIs [3]
  4. DevOps [5]
  5. Conclusions [2]
DevOps Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(21) From Projects to Products

  • Why are microservices an important development?
    • Decoupling teams for more autonomy which result in faster delivery
    • Components should be evolved and updated based on consumer feedback
    • Microservices are not (just) for development but (more importantly) for evolution
  • Traditional development has long cycles for product iterations
    • Creating requirements that are provided to a project team
    • Project teams deliver the result and move on to the next project
    • Products are operational but disconnected from their roots
    • Evolving products turns into another full project cycle
  • DevOps ensures that products can be evolved more effectively


DevOps Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(22) Lifecycle: From Idea to Production

  • Coding: code development and review, source code management tools, code merging
  • Building: continuous integration tools, build status
  • Testing: continuous testing tools that provide quick and timely feedback on business risks
  • Packaging: artifact repository, application pre-deployment staging
  • Releasing: change management, release approvals, release automation
  • Configuring: infrastructure configuration and management, infrastructure as code tools
  • Monitoring: applications performance monitoring, end-user experience


DevOps Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(23) ProductOps: From Value to Product

  • Speed is important but more important is the mindset
    • Delivering something fast is a great way to get feedback
    • Gathering and using feedback is part of product management
    • Using the feedback to change the product can be done easily and quickly
    • Rolling out changes should be a frequent process
  • Continuous improvement is the default and not the exception


DevOps Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(24) BizOps: From Mission to Value

  • How much speed do you need?
  • How much value does the speed generate?
    • How much potential is currently untapped because of too little speed?
    • How much speed do you need to realize (some of) that potential?
  • The business mindset needs to change as well
    • Looking at products as an opportunity to learn
    • Using insights for quick and small iterations
    • Focusing on quick initial delivery for market validation


DevOps Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(25) Software Engineering at Google [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Wdgjw6IGDM]

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity

(27) Changeability and Velocity

  • Microservices are a great way to move from systems to ecosystems
    • They are an implementation pattern and not a specific technology
  • DevOps is a great way to improve changeability and velocity of products
    • Start with modest goals of how quickly changes can be pushed to production


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Microservices and DevOps: Using APIs for Increased Velocity
